questions.latest version of HTML: As of my last update in January 2022, HTML5 is the latest version of HTML.
questions.main components of an HTML document: The main components of an HTML document include the document type declaration (<!DOCTYPE html>), the <html> element, the <head> element, and the <body> element.
questions.<!DOCTYPE html> declaration: The <!DOCTYPE html> declaration is used to specify the document type and version of HTML being used in the document. It helps browsers to render the web page correctly.
questions.HTML tag: An HTML tag is a keyword or code surrounded by angle brackets (< and >), which is used to define an element in an HTML document.
questions.HTML element: An HTML element is a complete set of an opening tag, content, and closing tag that defines a specific part of a web page's content or structure
questions.basic structure of an HTML document: The basic structure of an HTML document includes the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration, the <html> element, the <head> element, and the <body> element.
questions.<body> element in HTML: The <body> element is used to contain the main content of the HTML document, including text, images, links, and other elements.
questions.href attribute in the <a> tag: The href attribute in the <a> tag is used to specify the URL of the web page or resource that the hyperlink points to.
questions.self-closing tag in HTML: A self-closing tag in HTML is a tag that does not require a separate closing tag because it does not contain any content. It ends with a forward slash before the closing angle bracket, such as
questions.<title> element in HTML: The <title> element is used to define the title of the HTML document, which is displayed in the browser's title bar or tab
questions.id attribute: the id attribute in HTML is used to uniquely identify an element within a document. It is often used as a target for CSS styling or JavaScript manipulation.
questions.class attribute: The class attribute in HTML is used to specify one or more class names for an element, which can be used to apply CSS styling or JavaScript behavior to multiple elements with the same class
questions.<meta> tag in HTML: The <meta> tag is used to specify metadata about an HTML document, such as the character encoding, viewport settings, and other information that is not displayed on the page but is important for browsers and search engines
questions.HTML entities: HTML entities are special codes used to represent reserved characters, characters with special meaning in HTML, or characters that cannot be easily typed or displayed with a keyboard
questions.target attribute in the <a> tag: The target attribute in the <a> tag is used to specify the browsing context in which the linked document will be opened, such as in a new window (_blank) or in the same frame (_self).
questions.types of lists in HTML: The different types of lists in HTML are ordered lists (<ol>), unordered lists (<ul>), and definition lists (<dl>).
questions.<table> element in HTML: The <table> element is used to create a table in HTML, which consists of rows (<tr>), columns (<td> or <th>), and cell content.
questions.colspan and rowspan attributes in the <t: The colspan attribute specifies the number of columns a cell should span, and the rowspan attribute specifies the number of rows a cell should span in an HTML table.
questions.<form> element in HTML: The <form> element is used to create an HTML form, which is used to collect user input for submission to a server for processing.
questions.types of input fields in HTML forms: The different types of input fields in HTML forms include text fields (<input type=text>), password fields (<input type=password>), radio buttons (<input type=radio>), checkboxes (<input type=checkbox>), select dropdowns (<select>), and more..
questions.purpose of the required attribute in HTM: The required attribute is used to specify that an input field must be filled out before submitting the form. It is used for form validation.
questions.machine learning: Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that focuses on the development of algorithms that allow computers to learn from and make predictions or decisions based on data.
questions.types of machine learning: The main types of machine learning are supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and reinforcement learning.
questions.supervised learning: Supervised learning is a type of machine learning where the algorithm learns from labeled data, which means it is provided with input-output pairs during training.
questions.example of supervised learning: An example of supervised learning is email spam classification, where the algorithm learns to classify emails as spam or not spam based on labeled training data.
questions.unsupervised learning: Unsupervised learning is a type of machine learning where the algorithm learns from unlabeled data, meaning it must find patterns or structure in the input data on its own.
questions.example of unsupervised learning: An example of unsupervised learning is clustering similar documents together based on their content, without any prior labels.
questions.reinforcement learning: Reinforcement learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by interacting with an environment to achieve a goal, receiving rewards or penalties for its actions.
questions.firewall: A firewall is a network security device that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules. It acts as a barrier between a trusted internal network and untrusted external networks, such as the internet, to prevent unauthorized access while allowing legitimate communication.
questions.phishing attack: Phishing is a type of cyber attack where attackers send fraudulent emails or messages pretending to be from reputable organizations in order to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, or financial data.
questions.malware: Malware, short for malicious software, is any software intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, network, or device. Common types of malware include viruses, worms, Trojans, ransomware, spyware, and adware.
questions.encryption: Encryption is the process of converting plain text or data into a secret code (ciphertext) to prevent unauthorized access. It uses algorithms and keys to scramble the data, making it unreadable to anyone who does not have the corresponding decryption key.
questions.DDoS attack: A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack is a malicious attempt to disrupt the normal traffic of a targeted server, service, or network by overwhelming it with a flood of internet traffic from multiple sources. This renders the target inaccessible to its intended users.
questions.Two-Factor Authentication (2FA): Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) is a security process that requires users to provide two different authentication factors to verify their identity. These factors typically include something the user knows (like a password) and something the user has (like a mobile device or hardware token).
questions.VPN: A Virtual Private Network (VPN) creates a secure, encrypted connection over a less secure network, such as the internet. It allows users to securely access and transmit data over public networks as if their computing devices were directly connected to a private network, enhancing security and privacy.
questions.vulnerability assessment: A vulnerability assessment is the process of identifying, quantifying, and prioritizing vulnerabilities in a system or network. It typically involves scanning for weaknesses and flaws that could be exploited by attackers to compromise the security of the system.
questions.least privilege: The principle of least privilege is a security concept that states that users should be granted only the minimum level of access or permissions necessary to perform their job functions. This helps reduce the potential impact of a security breach by limiting the access that attackers can gain if they compromise a user account.
questions.Data Loss Prevention (DLP) system: A Data Loss Prevention (DLP) system is a security solution designed to prevent the unauthorized transmission or exfiltration of sensitive data from an organization's network. DLP systems monitor and control data in motion, at rest, and in use to ensure compliance with data security policies and regulations.
questions.SSL/TLS: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and Transport Layer Security (TLS) are cryptographic protocols that provide secure communication over a computer network. SSL/TLS encrypts data transmitted between a client and a server, preventing eavesdropping and tampering by unauthorized parties.
questions.SOC: A Security Operations Center (SOC) is a centralized facility equipped with security analysts, tools, and technologies to monitor, detect, analyze, and respond to cyber security incidents in real-time. SOCs play a crucial role in managing and mitigating security threats to protect organizational assets.
questions.Defense in Depth: The Principle of Defense in Depth is a security strategy that involves implementing multiple layers of security controls to protect information assets. This approach ensures that even if one layer of defense is breached, other layers remain intact to mitigate the impact of security incidents.
questions.Security Incident: A security incident is any event that jeopardizes the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of an organization's information assets. This includes unauthorized access, data breaches, malware infections, system outages, and other security breaches.
questions.Security Policy: A security policy is a set of rules, guidelines, and procedures established by an organization to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of its information assets. Security policies define the acceptable use of resources, access controls, data protection measures, and incident response procedures.
questions.Network Segmentation: Network segmentation is the practice of dividing a computer network into smaller subnetworks or segments to improve security and performance. By isolating different parts of the network, organizations can limit the impact of security breaches and control the flow of traffic to reduce the risk of unauthorized access.
questions.IDS: An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is a security tool that monitors network or system activities for malicious behavior or policy violations. IDSs analyze network traffic, log files, and other data sources to detect and alert administrators about potential security threats.
questions.Data Breach: A data breach is a security incident where sensitive, protected, or confidential data is accessed, stolen, or used by unauthorized individuals. This may involve personal information, financial data, intellectual property, or other sensitive data.
questions.Penetration Testing: Penetration testing, also known as pen testing or ethical hacking, is a simulated cyber attack against a computer system, network, or web application to identify security vulnerabilities that could be exploited by real attackers. It helps organizations assess their security posture and improve their defenses.
questions.Security Patch: A security patch is a software update released by vendors to fix vulnerabilities or weaknesses in their products. These patches are designed to address specific security issues and protect users from known threats. It's important for organizations and individuals to regularly apply security patches to keep their systems secure.
questions.Cryptographic Hash Function: A cryptographic hash function is a mathematical algorithm that converts an input (or 'message') into a fixed-size string of characters, which is typically a hexadecimal number. Hash functions are widely used in cryptography for data integrity verification, password hashing, digital signatures, and various other security applications.
